thread.title: Corruption Currents: Potential ZTE Deal Marches Forward Amid Congressional Objection

author: Samuel Rubenfeld
title: Corruption Currents: Potential ZTE Deal Marches Forward Amid Congressional Objection
text:
1 COMMENTS Visitors pass in front of the Chinese telecoms equipment group ZTE Corp. booth at the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona on Feb. 26, 2018. Photo: Reuters
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories via our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery:
Brazil’s embattled president decided against running for re-election. He denies wrongdoing in two corruption cases. (AP)
One former Macedonian premier was cleared of bribery charges; another was jailed in an unrelated case. (AP, BI, BBC)
Vietnamese skippers allegedly tried to bribe Malaysian maritime enforcement officials. The story didn’t contain a response. (NST)
U.S. authorities issued a warrant in a bribery case for a South African hunting guide. (AT)
Korean lawmakers voted down arrest motions on two of their colleagues. (KT)
Do bribes really buy votes ? (BBC)
A former Spanish minister was arrested on bribery charges; the story didn’t contain a response. (Xinhua)
Local cases: Four mayors and a city councillor were suspended in Australia following the signing of an antigraft law. Jurors want further instruction in a Long Island corruption trial. (SMH, Newsday)
Cybercrime:
U.S. officials warned Congress about the threats of hackers interfering with the 2018 elections. (Reuters)
Hackers can breach U.S. President Donald Trump’s phone because he’s refused to comply with security measures. (Politico, WP)
U.K. banks say they need more cybersecurity technology. (Bloomberg)
U.S. and Canadian regulators opened probes into cryptocurrency scams. (Reuters, WP)
The Pentagon embraced a plan to hack and disable nuclear weapons before they launch. (DB)
Fraud:
Families sued a Washington, D.C., school following reports of enrollment fraud. Authorities declined to comment. (WP)
Money Laundering:
Nigerian authorities are pursuing multiple money-laundering investigations against former governors . (Vanguard, PT, Punch, TD, TD, TD)
Turkish prosecutors are investigating Cypriot casinos for money laundering. (DS)
Six people were charged with money laundering as part of an investigation into fake Louis XIV furniture. (AN)
Indian authorities continue pursuing money - laundering cases . (ToI, Hindu, LM, ToI, PTI, NIE)
Sanctions:
President Trump mused about potential management changes at ZTE Corp. as a potential remedy , instead of further sanctions, as a personal favor to the Chinese president. Lawmakers vowed to block him. The company is losing billions amid the political discussions . (Reuters, Politico, AP, SCMP, Bloomberg, NPR, Bloomberg, Bloomberg, WP)
Does the U.S. risk war with Iran? There’s no alternative to the Iran nuclear deal, the EU said. Tehran said European support isn’t enough. The U.S. said European companies will have to comply with sanctions. BP PLC delayed work with Iran due to U.S. sanctions risk. Poland took the U.S. side. German banks and an Austrian firm stood with Iran. (BBC, EA, Reuters, MW, BBC, WP, Handesblatt, Reuters)
General Anticorruption:
Michael Cohen’s business ties are coming under increasing scrutiny . He’s become a pariah in Mr. Trump’s world. (NYT, BBC, DB)
The U.S. special counsel ‘s investigation continues as President Trump keeps up his attacks on investigators . Who was the informant ? Do his business ties call for their own probe? (Bloomberg, Haaretz, AP, CNN, NPR, DB, HP, HP, Politico, Politico, WP, Atlantic)
U.S. Democrats unveiled an anticorruption campaign platform for 2018 midterm elections amid scandal s that are plaguing the Trump administration. (WP, Vox, NY, Vice, Atlantic, DB)
Malaysian authorities questioned the former premier as they investigate the 1MDB case. The investigator describes receiving death threats. (Bloomberg, AP, Reuters, Guardian, Reuters)
Ukraine’s president said he’s listened to foreign partners while drafting anticorruption legislation. (Reuters)
FIFA ended a doping probe into Russian soccer players. (AFP, release)
An Italian reporter covering the mafia has police protection . (NYT)
